headline: The Taylor Wilderness Research Station
description: The Big Creek site where Taylor Wilderness Research Station (TWRS) is located has been occupied or utilized in some form by humans for at least 10,000 years. Far from being an area “where man is but a visitor who does not remain”, TWRS is a chapter in a human social drama as rich and dynamic as the “untrammeled” ecological processes of the surrounding Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness.

headline: The Brand
description: The University of Idaho acquired the property from Jess and Dorothy Taylor in 1969, who bought the property from David “Cougar Dave” Lewis in 1935, who had originally designed this livestock brand that is still used today.

headline: The Landscape
description: An appreciation for the site's capacity to attract and sustain various human geographies alongside such wild and remote terrain is therefore critical to understanding the physical and biological environment of Taylor.

headline: The People
description: The verbiage of “wilderness field station” suggests minimal or peripheral social life, yet the site’s longstanding association with human activity—from indigenous peoples, to settlers, and later scientists—has been integral to forming the greater ecological community known simply as ‘Taylor’.

headline: Social and Experiential
description: This oral history project explores both the social and ecological dimensions of Taylor Wilderness Research Station through recorded interviews with past and present researchers, teachers, station managers, and students. Interviews focused on uncovering often-ignored social and experiential content behind scientific pursuit, offering a narrative index of social-ecological change within a wilderness environment.
